lead_paragraph: Judge Frederic Block in Brooklyn declined to incarcerate a woman found with cocaine and urged the courts to take a closer look at the effect felony convictions have on people’s lives.

headline.print_headline: U.S. Judge, in Striking Move, Sentences Felon to Probation, Not Prison
headline.main: U.S. Judge’s Striking Move in Felony Drug Case: Probation, Not Prison

snippet: Judge Frederic Block in Brooklyn declined to incarcerate a woman found with cocaine and urged the courts to take a closer look at the effect felony convictions have on people’s lives.
abstract: Federal Judge Frederic Block in Brooklyn issues extraordinary opinion in sentencing Chevelle Nesbeth, charged with felony drug possession, to probation instead of prison; cites collateral consequences of felony drug convictions, saying likely result of prison time is ruined life and ultimately recidivism; ruling will not set binding legal precedent for other courts, but is likely to contribute to national debate over sentencing reform.
